docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The Asset Management System (AMS) is a Python-based console application designed to manage and track various assets within an organization. This system provides functionalities such as creating, reading, updating, and deleting assets, as well as searching for assets based on specific criteria. Additionally, users can log in to the system, and account information is securely stored.

docs.title: Table Of Contents
docs.text:
• Overview
  • Installation
  • User Management
  • Create User
  • Log In
  • Asset Management
  • Create Asset
  • Read Asset
  • Update Asset
  • Delete Asset
  • Search Asset
  • Logging
  • Dependencies
  • Conclusion

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Asset Management System is designed to provide a user-friendly interface for managing assets, making it easier for organizations to keep track of their inventory. The system allows users to perform various operations related to both user management and asset management.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To install and use the Asset Management System, click here.

This will take you to our release page where you'll find and download the executable.

docs.title: Create User
docs.text: The system allows administrators to create new user accounts securely. Usernames and passwords are stored in a CSV file with hashed passwords for security.

docs.title: Log In
docs.text: Users can log in to the system using their credentials. The system validates the entered information against the stored data to grant or deny access.

docs.title: Create Asset
docs.text: Users can add new assets to the system by providing relevant information such as serial number, category, type, location, assignee, description, color, and status.

docs.title: Read Assets
docs.text: The system provides multiple options for viewing assets, including a spreadsheet view, PDF view, and a default terminal view

docs.title: Update Asset
docs.text: Users can update existing asset information by specifying the serial number and the field to be updated. The system logs changes for audit purposes.

docs.title: Delete Asset
docs.text: Assets can be removed from the system by providing the serial number. The system logs the deletion for tracking purposes.

docs.title: Search Assets
docs.text: Users can search for assets based on various criteria, such as ID, serial number, category, type, location, assignee, description, color, or status.

docs.title: Logging
docs.text: The system logs user activities, including login attempts, asset creations, updates, deletions, and searches. The logs are stored in separate log files for both user activities and asset activities.

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
The Asset Management System relies on the following Python libraries:

colorama: Used for terminal text colorization.

tabulate: Facilitates tabular data formatting for a better display.

csv2pdf: Enables the conversion of CSV data to PDF format.

pywriter: A utility library for printing characters in the classic typewriter effect.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: The Asset Management System provides a flexible and efficient solution for organizations to manage their assets effectively. Regular updates and improvements may be made to enhance the functionality and security of the system. Users are encouraged to refer to the documentation for any queries or assistance.

docs.title: GridCode Asset Management System
docs.text: The Asset Management System is a Python program designed to manage information about assets in a CSV file. This document provides an overview of the code structure, its functionalities, and how to use the system.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Introduction
  • Getting Started
  • Code Structure
  • Usage
  • Contributing
  • Suggesting Enhancements
  • License

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The Asset Management System is implemented in Python and utilizes CSV files for storing asset information. The system allows users to create, read, update, and delete assets, providing a simple interface for managing asset data.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: To use the Asset Management System, follow these steps:

docs.title: Clone the Repository:
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/amarquaye/gridcode.git
cd gridcode

docs.title: Run the program:
docs.text: python main.py

docs.title: Initialization:
docs.text:
def __init__(self):
    self.file_exists = os.path.isfile('assets.csv')
    self.ID = 'ID'
    self.SN = 'SN'
    # ... (other column headers)
    self.STATUS = 'STATUS'
    logging.basicConfig(filename='assets.log', level=logging.INFO,
                        format='%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s: %(message)s',
                        datefmt='%A, %Y-%m-%d %I:%M:%S %p')

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Initializes the AssetManagementSystem. Checks if the 'assets.csv' file exists. Defines column headers for the CSV file. Configures logging to log activities to 'assets.log'.

docs.title: log_activity Method:
docs.text:
def log_activity(self, message):
    logging.info(message)

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Logs an activity message using the logging module.

docs.title: get_last_asset_id Method:
docs.text:
def get_last_asset_id(self):
    try:
        with open('assets.csv', 'r', newline='') as csvfile:
            reader = csv.DictReader(csvfile)
            rows = list(reader)
            if rows:
                return int(rows[-1]['ID'])
            else:
                return 0
    except FileNotFoundError:
        return 0

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Reads the 'assets.csv' file to get the last asset ID. Returns 0 if the file doesn't exist.

docs.title: create_asset Method:
docs.text:
def create_asset(self):
    # ... (prompting user for asset details)
    try:
        with open('assets.csv', 'a', newline='') as csvfile:
            # ... (writing the new asset to the CSV file)
        print(f"Asset '{sn}' added successfully!\n")
    except PermissionError:
        print("Cannot access file\nPlease close your spreadsheet reader and try again!")

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Prompts the user for asset details. Checks for serial number uniqueness. Appends the new asset to 'assets.csv'. Logs the activity. Handles PermissionError if the file is open in another application.

docs.title: is_serial_number_unique Method:
docs.text:
def is_serial_number_unique(self, serial_number):
    with open('assets.csv', 'r', newline='') as csvfile:
        reader = csv.DictReader(csvfile)
        for row in reader:
            if row[self.SN] == serial_number:
                return False
    return True

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Checks if a given serial number is unique in the 'assets.csv' file.

docs.title: read_assets Method:
docs.text:
def read_assets(self):

    elif read_choice == "3":

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Allows the user to choose how to view assets (spreadsheet, PDF, or default terminal view). Logs the activity.

docs.title: search_assets Method:
docs.text:
def search_assets(self):
    # ... (prompting user for search criteria)
    try:
        with open('assets.csv', 'r', newline='') as csvfile:
            # ... (searching and displaying found assets)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("No assets found.\n")
    except KeyError:
        print("Entry can't be found or you mispelt an entry!")
        main()

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Prompts the user for search criteria. Searches assets based on the specified column and value. Displays found assets in a tabulated format. Logs the activity. Handles FileNotFoundError and KeyError.

docs.title: update_asset Method:
docs.text:
def update_asset(self):
    # ... (prompting user for asset and update details)
    try:
        with open('assets.csv', 'r', newline='') as csvfile:
            # ... (updating the asset and logging the activity)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("No assets found.\n")

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Prompts the user for the serial number and the field to update. Updates the specified field of an asset. Logs the old and new values. Writes the updated assets to 'assets.csv'. Handles FileNotFoundError.

docs.title: delete_asset Method:
docs.text:
def delete_asset(self):
    # ... (prompting user for asset details)
    try:
        with open('assets.csv', 'r', newline='') as csvfile:
            # ... (deleting the asset and logging the activity)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("No assets found.\n")

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Prompts the user for the serial number of the asset to delete. Deletes the specified asset. Logs the deletion activity. Writes the remaining assets to 'assets.csv'. Handles FileNotFoundError.

docs.title: init Method:
docs.text:
def __init__(self):
    self.log_file = 'activity.log'

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Initializes the UserManager with a log file.

docs.title: log_activity Method:
docs.text:
def log_activity(self, message):
    timestamp = datetime.now().strftime("%A, %Y-%m-%d %I:%M:%S %p")
    with open(self.log_file, 'a') as log_file:
        log_file.write(f"{timestamp} {message}\n")

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Logs user activities with a timestamp.

docs.title: login Method:
docs.text:
def login(self, username, password):
    # ... (checks username and verifies password)
    return True/False

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Authenticates a user by checking the username and password against stored data. Logs successful logins.

docs.title: create_account Method:
docs.text:
def create_account(self, username, password):
    # ... (creates a new user account and logs the activity)
    return True/False

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Creates a new user account. Hashes the password before storing it. Logs the account creation

docs.title: hash_password Method:
docs.text:
def hash_password(self, password):
    return hashlib.sha256(password.encode()).hexdigest()

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Hashes a given password using SHA-256.

docs.title: verify_password Method:
docs.text:
def verify_password(self, stored_password, entered_password):
    return stored_password == self.hash_password(entered_password)

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Verifies a password against a stored hashed password during login.

docs.text:
def print_yellow(text, rate=0.001):
    # ... (prints text in yellow with a specified printing rate)

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Prints text in yellow with a specified printing rate.

docs.title: display_menu Function:

def display_menu():

docs.text: Displays the main menu for login.

docs.title: login Function:
docs.text:
def login(user_manager):
    # ... (takes user input for username and password)

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Takes user input for username and password. Calls user_manager.login for authentication.

docs.title: create_user Function:
docs.text:
def create_user(user_manager):
    # ... (takes user input for a new username and password)

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Takes user input for a new username and password. Calls user_manager.create_account to create a new user.

docs.title: Main Execution (name == "main"):
docs.text:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    # ... (prints colorful ASCII art)
    user_manager = UserManager()
    while True:
        # ... (displays login menu and executes user choice)

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text: Initializes the Asset Management System (asset_system). Prints colorful ASCII art. Loops through the main menu after a successful login.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Run the program by executing python main.py

Choose from the following options:

Create Asset (1): Enter details for a new asset. Read Assets (2): View a list of all assets. Update Asset (3): Modify details of an existing asset. Delete Asset (4): Remove a specific asset. Search Asset (5): Search for assets based on a specified criteria. Exit (6): Terminate the program.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Contributions to the Asset Management System are welcome. Please follow the guidelines outlined below. - Fork the repository on GitHub. - Clone your forked repository to your local machine. - Make changes in your local repository. - Push your changes to your fork on GitHub. - Submit a pull request.

docs.title: Suggesting Enhancements
docs.text:
To suggest an enhancement, create a GitHub Issue with the following information:

  • A clear and descriptive title.
  • A detailed description of the enhancement.
  • If possible, provide examples or use cases.

docs.title: Code Review Process
docs.text:
• All contributions will be reviewed by a maintainer.
  • Feedback will be provided, and necessary changes may be requested.

docs.title: License
docs.text: By contributing to the Asset Management System, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the Apache 2.0.
